fields.label_text:
Displayed above:
Quilted Jacket designed and made for Eddie Squires by Vicki Nigoumi
The fabric is Gemstones, a screen-printed cotton furnishing fabric designed by Eddie Squires for Warner and Sons Ltd
British, 1971

In 1971 Eddie Squires took over as chief designer at Warner and Sons and Gemstones was put into hand on the 21 April that year.  The design required nine flat bed screens and can be read on two levels: it is a close-up depiction of  the play of light on the crystalline surfaces of cut glass and jewels and with upright forms composed of separate gems it echoes the hard-edged, soaring architecture of modern cities such as Manhattan.  Initially put together as a collage of jewels from books on minerals and gemstones, the whole resembles the silhouette of a twentieth century steel and glass city floating through space. 

In the case of Gemstones, part of the Minerals Collection, the fabric only reached prototype stage and was never stocked.  Although the repeat pattern is large, it is effective as a series of isolated motifs on this jacket.  


T.973-2000





Displayed to the side:
A montage of photographs of Eddie Squires created for this display by Sue Palmer, who worked with Eddie as a designer at Warner & Sons Ltd.
Some of the photographs have been provided by Janice Boughton, Muriel Kitchen and Sue Palmer; others have been copied from Eddie's scrapbooks which are in the Department of Prints, Drawings & Paintings.



 Left:
Microchip and Vine
Sample of screen-printed cotton furnishing
Designed by Eddie Squires for Warners and Sons Ltd
British 1981

Eddie took pride in the fact that the Warner Design Studio was able to supply the demands of a varied market with everything 'from silk damasks to the artisan beauty of block-printing.'  He said they were able to work 'with the past for the future, their document reproductions reaching higher standards all the time.' The Studio was very broad-minded in its acceptance of differing styles and he thought this was of great importance because the traditional mood might ebb and the world might move to alternative styles. By superimposing a traditional floral trail on to a pattern of microchip circuitry he shows how the two are easily combined.

T.1008-2000

Right:
Microchip 
Sample of screen-printed cotton furnishing
Designed by Eddie Squires for Warners and Sons Ltd
British 1981

T.1009-2000
 Gemstones
Sample of screen-printed cotton furnishing fabric 
Designed by Eddie Squires for Warner and Sons Ltd
British, 1971

Initially put together as a collage of cut jewels taken from books on minerals and gemstones, the whole design eventually resembled the profile of a twentieth century steel and glass city floating through space on grassy hillocks.

A jacket displayed on the opposite wall uses Gemstones to great effect.

Eddie believed in acknowledging the designer's name and the title of the fabric on the selvedge of original textile designs and he also advocated lively discussion between the Designer and the Buyer at events such as Trade Fairs - he wanted to remind the Buyer of the human personality and complex artistic process behind the creation of specific textiles.

T.359A-1990

fields.descriptive_line: Jacket of screen printed and quilted cotton, purple, with a pattern of faceted gemstones and pink roses and with green hems, furnishing fabric, 20th century.

fields.name: To Boldly Go: a tribute to the textile designer Eddie Squires

fields.physical_description: Jacket of screen printed and quilted cotton, purple, with a pattern of faceted gemstones and pink roses. All hems are green. There are two large pockets on the front and a smaller one on the right arm. The three buttons are covered in the same fabric from which the jacket is made and there are no button holes, but tailored loops. The shoulders are tailored to imitate epaulettes. The jacket is made from a fabric called Gemstone and produced by Warner Fabrics PLC. It is the same as T.953-2000 but in a different colour scheme.
fields.dimensions: Width: 51 cm at hem, Width: 136 cm across shoulders, Length: 70 cm middle axis of back

fields.exhibition_history: To Boldly Go: a tribute to the textile designer Eddie Squires (Victoria and Albert Museum 01/01/0001-19/03/2002)
